options.label: D
options.text: Social integration only affected short-term memory.

multiple-choice.question: What is one way to aid your brain in preserving memories?

options.label: C
options.text: Exposing your brain to challenges, such as learning a new language

multiple-choice.question: What happens to the hippocampus as we age?

options.label: A
options.text: It grows and develops new neurons

options.label: C
options.text: It loses 5% of its neurons every decade

multiple-choice.question: Why are memories encoded most strongly when we're paying attention, deeply engaged, and when information is meaningful to us?

options.label: A
options.text: Because our brain is less active during these times

options.label: B
options.text: Because our brain is more receptive to new information during these times

options.label: C
options.text: Because our brain is able to filter out distractions during these times

options.label: D
options.text: Because our brain is able to store information more efficiently during these times

title: Growth Mindset vs Fixed Mindset: An Introduction

multiple-choice.question: What do people with a growth mindset believe about intelligence?

options.label: D
options.text: It is only determined by environment

multiple-choice.question: How do people with a fixed mindset view intelligence?

options.label: A
options.text: Like a muscle that can be developed

options.label: B
options.text: Like eye color that cannot be changed

options.label: C
options.text: Like a skill that can be learned

options.label: D
options.text: Like a talent that is innate

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the main goal for students with a fixed mindset in school?

options.label: B
options.text: To show how smart they are or hide how unintelligent they are

options.label: C
options.text: To make friends and have fun

multiple-choice.question: Why do students with a fixed mindset avoid asking questions when they don't understand something?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they don't want to bother the teacher

options.label: C
options.text: Because they want to preserve the image that they are smart

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are not interested in learning

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a growth mindset view effort?

options.label: C
options.text: As the way to learn and get smarter

options.label: D
options.text: As only necessary for difficult tasks

multiple-choice.question: What happens when students with a fixed mindset are faced with a challenge or setback?
Why do students with a growth mindset like challenges?

options.label: B
options.text: Because they are a way to prove themselves

options.label: C
options.text: Because they are an opportunity to learn and develop their intelligence

options.label: D
options.text: Because they are a way to show off their skills

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is the relationship between having a growth mindset and doing well in school?

options.label: B
options.text: Students with a growth mindset do worse in school

options.label: C
options.text: Students with a growth mindset do better in school

multiple-choice.question: How do students with a growth mindset approach school differently than students with a fixed mindset?

options.label: A
options.text: They are more focused on grades

options.label: B
options.text: They are more focused on learning

options.label: C
options.text: They are more focused on socializing

options.label: D
options.text: They are more focused on extracurricular activities

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between students with a fixed mindset and students with a growth mindset?

options.label: C
options.text: Their view of intelligence as fixed or developable

title: Vatican City Explained

multiple-choice.question: What is the approximate time it takes to circumnavigate Vatican City on foot?
Which Italian leader struck a deal with the Pope to establish Vatican City as a separate country?
What was the name of the country ruled by the Popes for over 1,000 years?
What is the name of the largest church in the world built by the Popes?
Why is Vatican City not a member of the European Union?

options.label: D
options.text: It does not meet economic requirements

multiple-choice.question: What is the term used to refer to the Pope's throne and the rules that govern the Catholic Church?
Who has absolute power within the borders of Vatican City?
How does one become a citizen of Vatican City?
What is unique about the monarchy of Vatican City?

options.label: D
options.text: It is both elected and absolute

multiple-choice.question: Why is Vatican City best described as a "Sovereign Corporate Headquarters"?

options.label: A
options.text: Because it has a large population

options.label: B
options.text: Because it has a diverse economy

options.label: C
options.text: Because it grants temporary citizenship to its managers

title: The treadmill's dark and twisted past - Conor Heffernan

multiple-choice.question: What was the primary purpose of the treadmill when it was first introduced in English prisons in the 1800s?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide prisoners with a form of entertainment

options.label: B
options.text: To reform prisoners through physical labor and rehabilitation

options.label: C
options.text: To punish prisoners for their crimes

multiple-choice.question: Who is credited with inventing the original treadmill in 1818?
What was the name of the act that banned treadmills in England in the late 19th century?

options.label: B
options.text: The Cruel and Unusual Punishment Act

multiple-choice.question: How many hours a day, on average, did prisoners spend on treadmills?
What was the equivalent height that prisoners would climb in a day on the treadmill?
What was the benefit of the treadmill, apart from punishing prisoners?

options.label: A
options.text: It helped to power the prison's facilities

options.label: B
options.text: It provided prisoners with a form of entertainment

options.label: C
options.text: It helped to rebuild the British economy

options.label: D
options.text: It reduced the number of prison guards needed

multiple-choice.question: Who credited the treadmill with taming his more boisterous inmates?
In what year was a treadmill patent registered in the U.S.?
What was the primary reason for the treadmill's resurgence in popularity in the 1970s?

options.label: D
options.text: The growing awareness of the importance of strength training

multiple-choice.question: What is the main difference between the original treadmill and the modern treadmill?

options.label: A
options.text: The original treadmill was powered by electricity, while the modern treadmill is manual

options.label: B
options.text: The original treadmill was used for punishment, while the modern treadmill is used for exercise and fitness

options.label: C
options.text: The original treadmill was only used in prisons, while the modern treadmill is used in gyms and homes

options.label: D
options.text: The original treadmill was more expensive than the modern treadmill

title: What happens when your DNA is damaged? - Monica Menesini

multiple-choice.question: How many times does the DNA in one cell get damaged per day?
What is the primary function of DNA in a cell?

options.label: A
options.text: To provide energy for the cell

options.label: C
options.text: To provide the blueprint for proteins

multiple-choice.question: What type of error occurs when nucleotides get matched up incorrectly during DNA replication?
What is the name of the enzyme responsible for correcting base mismatches during DNA replication?
What is the process called when a second set of proteins checks for and corrects base mismatches after DNA replication?
What is the name of the process that repairs damage caused by UV light, where two adjacent nucleotides stick together?
What type of radiation can cause double-strand breaks in DNA?
What is the name of the process that repairs double-strand breaks by using an undamaged section of similar DNA as a template?
What is the result of defects in DNA repair pathways?

options.label: A
options.text: Premature aging and many kinds of cancer

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the process that repairs double-strand breaks by trimming off a few nucleotides and fusing the broken ends back together?

title: Freedom to Change

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the person who started practicing meditation in prison and later founded the Prison Mindfulness Institute?
According to Roberta Richman, what is the key to keeping an institution safe for everybody who lives in it?

options.label: B
options.text: Controlling all of their movement and behavior

options.label: D
options.text: Encouraging prisoners to participate in recreational activities

multiple-choice.question: What is the primary reason why many people end up in prison, according to Fleet Maull?

options.label: C
options.text: Lack of good problem-solving skills and good communication skills

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the woman who is serving a life term in prison?
Conceptual question: What does Fleet Maull mean by "owning my own situation" in the context of prison life?

options.label: C
options.text: Giving up hope for a better life

options.label: D
options.text: Ignoring the reality of one's situation

multiple-choice.question: Application question: How can meditation help prisoners change their behavior and become better people?

options.label: A
options.text: By providing a way to escape reality

options.label: B
options.text: By teaching them how to fight and defend themselves

options.label: C
options.text: By giving them a tool to look inside themselves and change their thoughts and behaviors

options.label: D
options.text: By offering a way to blame others for their circumstances

multiple-choice.question: Analytical question: What does Roberta Richman mean by "the soft stuff" in the context of prison rehabilitation?

options.label: A
options.text: The physical infrastructure of the prison

options.label: B
options.text: The rules and regulations of the prison

options.label: C
options.text: The programs and services that help prisoners change their behavior and become better people

options.label: D
options.text: The food and amenities provided to prisoners

multiple-choice.question: Factual question: How many people will return home from prison this year, according to the transcript?
Conceptual question: What is the main idea of the transcript in terms of prison rehabilitation?

options.label: A
options.text: That prisoners are beyond redemption and should be punished harshly

options.label: B
options.text: That prisons should focus on providing vocational training and job skills

options.label: C
options.text: That meditation and mindfulness can help prisoners change their behavior and become better people

options.label: D
options.text: That prisons should prioritize punishment over rehabilitation

multiple-choice.question: Analytical question: What is the implication of Roberta Richman's statement "The people in prison are us"?

options.label: A
options.text: That prisoners are a separate and distinct group from the rest of society

options.label: B
options.text: That prisoners are monsters and should be treated as such

options.label: C
options.text: That prisoners are human beings who deserve to be treated with dignity and respect

options.label: D
options.text: That prisoners are only in prison because of their own failures and weaknesses

title: The mathematical secrets of Pascal’s triangle - Wajdi Mohamed Ratemi

multiple-choice.question: What is the name of the triangle in the Western world, named after a French mathematician?
What is the pattern that generates Pascal's Triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: Start with zero and add the numbers in each row

options.label: B
options.text: Start with one and imagine invisible zeros on either side of it, then add them together in pairs

options.label: C
options.text: Start with two and multiply the numbers in each row

options.label: D
options.text: Start with three and subtract the numbers in each row

multiple-choice.question: What does each row in Pascal's Triangle correspond to?

options.label: A
options.text: The coefficients of a binomial expansion of the form (x-y)^n

options.label: B
options.text: The coefficients of a binomial expansion of the form (x+y)^n

options.label: C
options.text: The coefficients of a polynomial expansion of the form (x+y)^2

options.label: D
options.text: The coefficients of a polynomial expansion of the form (x-y)^2

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of adding up the numbers in each row of Pascal's Triangle?
What is the result of treating each number in a given row as part of a decimal expansion?
What are the numbers in the next diagonal after the positive integers called?
What is the result of shading in all of the odd numbers in Pascal's Triangle?

options.label: B
options.text: A fractal known as Sierpinski's Triangle

multiple-choice.question: What is the probability of having three girls and two boys in a family of five children?
How many possible groups of five are there when randomly picking a five-player basketball team out of a group of twelve friends?

options.label: A
options.text: The fifth element of row twelve on the triangle

options.label: B
options.text: The sixth element of row twelve on the triangle

options.label: C
options.text: The seventh element of row twelve on the triangle

options.label: D
options.text: The eighth element of row twelve on the triangle

multiple-choice.question: What is the significance of the patterns in Pascal's Triangle?

options.label: A
options.text: They are a testament to the complexity of mathematics

options.label: B
options.text: They are a testament to the elegantly interwoven fabric of mathematics

options.label: C
options.text: They are a testament to the randomness of mathematics

options.label: D
options.text: They are a testament to the simplicity of mathematics

title: How misused modifiers can hurt your writing

multiple-choice.question: What is a misplaced modifier in grammar?

options.label: A
options.text: A phrase that clearly explains the subject of a sentence

options.label: B
options.text: A word or phrase that adds information about other parts of a sentence but is not linked clearly

options.label: C
options.text: A type of punctuation used to separate clauses

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sentence structure used for emphasis

multiple-choice.question: What is the main issue with the original sentence "Thief robs town with world's largest chocolate bunny"?

options.label: C
options.text: The modifying phrase is not clearly linked to the intended word

options.label: D
options.text: The sentence is in the wrong tense

multiple-choice.question: What is a dangling modifier in grammar?

options.label: A
options.text: A modifier that is clearly linked to the subject of a sentence

options.label: B
options.text: A modifier that appears to be modifying nothing at all

options.label: C
options.text: A type of sentence structure used for emphasis

options.label: D
options.text: A type of punctuation used to separate clauses

multiple-choice.question: How can you correct a sentence with a dangling modifier?

options.label: B
options.text: By giving the modifier something to modify

options.label: C
options.text: By changing the sentence structure to passive voice

multiple-choice.question: What is a squinting modifier in grammar?

options.label: A
options.text: A modifier that is clearly linked to the subject of a sentence

options.label: B
options.text: A modifier that appears to be modifying nothing at all

options.label: C
options.text: A modifier that is stuck between two things and could refer to either

options.label: D
options.text: A type of sentence structure used for emphasis

multiple-choice.question: What is often the type of word that acts as a squinting modifier?
How can you clarify a sentence with a squinting modifier?

options.label: B
options.text: By putting the modifier closer to its intended phrase

options.label: C
options.text: By changing the sentence structure to passive voice

multiple-choice.question: What is the main goal of avoiding verbal ambiguity in writing?

options.label: C
options.text: To make it clear which parts of the sentence modifiers belong to

multiple-choice.question: What is the effect of a misplaced modifier on the meaning of a sentence?

options.label: A
options.text: It makes the sentence more clear

options.label: B
options.text: It has no effect on the meaning

options.label: C
options.text: It can dramatically change the meaning of a sentence

options.label: D
options.text: It makes the sentence more concise

multiple-choice.question: Why is it important to link modifiers clearly to the words they modify?

options.label: B
options.text: To avoid verbal ambiguity and ensure clear meaning

options.label: D
options.text: To change the sentence structure to passive voice
